name: Municipal Fee Assistance Program (MFAP)
description: Provides discounted access to City recreation programs, transit passes, garbage tags, and other municipal services for low-income Kingston residents. Also provides access to partner services like dental care, vision care, and Lionhearts Fresh Food Market discounts.
eligibility:
The Municipal Fee Assistance Program (MFAP) is an income-based program. It provides access to our services and programs for free or at a lower cost.
We use the Statistics Canada after-tax Low-Income Measure (LIM) plus 15 percent to determine eligibility.

We offer different programs that support low- and moderate-income households. You only need to apply once to MFAP to access the discounts. We provide funding on a first-come, first-served basis until we reach the yearly budget.

* Does not include dental treatment received before your eligibility was determined.
* If you spend three or four per cent of your after-tax household income on prescription drugs, you can access the Trillium Drug Program.

You can use SPARK to pay for programs, memberships or single-use passes. It is given out on a first-come, first-served basis until the yearly budget is used up.

We use the Statistics Canada after-tax Low-Income Measure (LIM) plus 15 percent to determine eligibility.
We offer different programs that support low- and moderate-income households. You only need to apply once to MFAP to access the discounts. We provide funding on a first-come, first-served basis until we reach the yearly budget.

Municipal Fee Assistance Program | City of Kingston
# Municipal Fee Assistance Program
The Municipal Fee Assistance Program (MFAP) is an income-based program. It provides access to our services and programs for free or at a lower cost.
We use the Statistics Canada after-tax Low-Income Measure (LIM) plus 15 percent to determine eligibility.
LIM thresholds for 2026
Thresholds include additional 15%.
* 1-person household - $34,793
* 2-person household - $49,205
* 3-person household - $60,263
* 4-person household - $69,587
* 5-person household - $77,800
* 6-person household - $85,225
* 7-person household - $92,054
* 8-person household - $98,410
* 9-person household - $104,380
* 10-person household - $110,020
## Services provided
We offer different programs that support low- and moderate-income households. You only need to apply once to MFAP to access the discounts. We provide funding on a first-come, first-served basis until we reach the yearly budget.
The Subsidy Program for Affordable Recreation in Kingston (SPARK) helps reduce the cost of our recreation programs for Kingston residents.
SPARK provides free access to our:
Each eligible family member can also receive up to $300 every year to put toward recreation and leisure programs.Learn more about the[Affordable Recreation Program](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/activities-and-recreation/affordable-recreation-program/).
If your MFAP card is valid beyond December 31, you can reapply for next year’s funding by emailing [contactus@cityofkingston.ca](mailto:contactus@cityofkingston.ca). Please note that processing typically takes 5–10 business days.
You can get a discounted renewable monthly transit pass. Learn more about the[Transit Fares and Passes](https://www.kingstontransit.ca/fares-and-passes/standard-fares-and-passes/)[](https://www.kingstontransit.ca/fares-and-passes/).
Extended health care benefits
The Low-Income Health Benefit Program applies if you are a resident who is not on Ontario Works or the Ontario Disability Support Program. It helps you with vision, dental, and prescription medication expenses.
##### Adult dental care
You must be 18 years or older (if you are 17 and younger you are covered under the Healthy Smiles program). If you are 65 years of age or older you can apply for the Canadian Dental Care Program (CDCP) which is a government funded program that provides free, routine dental services for low-income seniors.
* Includes routine cleaning, emergency restorative and preventative dental and denture care services.
* Does not include dental treatment received before your eligibility was determined.
##### Vision care
* Eye exam applies for those who are between 20 to 64 years old (OHIP covers eye examinations for people under 20 and 65 or older).
* It also includes prescription eyeglass lenses and frames or contact lenses (where appropriate) for people of all ages.
##### Prescription medications
* The Ontario Drug Benefit Plan covers medications for individuals between 25 to 64 years of age. An authorized healthcare provider must prescribe these medications, and they should be listed in the[Ontario Drug Benefit Formulary](https://www.formulary.health.gov.on.ca/formulary/).
* OHIP+ provides free medications for all children and youth up to 24 years of age.
* If you spend three or four per cent of your after-tax household income on prescription drugs, you can access the Trillium Drug Program.
You can receive a $10 discount on fresh fruits, vegetables and prepared foods at the Lionhearts Fresh Food Market Pop-ups. Review the list of[market pop-up locations](https://www.lionhearts.ca/popup) across Kingston.
You can purchase garbage bag tags at a reduced price of $2 at certain City facilities. Please bring your MFAP card with you. You may buy a maximum of 25 bag tags at a time.
Discounted bag tags are only available at the following locations:
* Planning & Building Services (1211 John Counter Blvd.)
Bags tags sold at other third-party retailers (such as grocery or convenience stores) will remain at $4.
Grand OnSTAGE offers discounted tickets to Municipal Fee Assistance Program members. Review the [Grand Theatre Discount Programs](https://www.kingstongrand.ca/tickets/discount-programs) and find more details on MFAP pricing under 'More Ways to Save'.
You can receive 50 per cent off the marriage licence fee. Learn more about [marriage licences and ceremonies](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/applications-licences-and-permits/marriage-licences-and-ceremonies/).
The PumpHouse Museum offers a 50 per cent discount on general admission, season passes, and tours at any time during the season. Learn more about the [Kingston PumpHouse Museum](https://www.kingstonpumphouse.ca/).
You might be eligible for a $250 voucher toward the cost of having your pet spayed or neutered at any veterinarian clinic in Kingston. Learn more about[Animal and Pet Services](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/bylaws-and-animal-services/animal-and-pet-services/).

Canadian Dental Care Plan - What is covered - Canada.ca
# What services are covered
## Services covered
The Canadian Dental Care Plan (CDCP) will help pay a portion of the cost for a wide range of oral health care services. Many services are covered without preauthorization, and others require preauthorization.
Examples of services that could be covered under the CDCP when recommended by an oral health provider include:
* ### Diagnostic and preventive services
These are services to check your oral health status, keep your teeth, gums and mouth healthy, and prevent cavities and gum disease and detect mouth conditions (like cancer) earlier. CDCP covers:
* fluoride applications
* ### Basic services
#### Restorative services
These services treat cavities and broken teeth. CDCP covers:
#### Endodontic services
These services treat teeth that are severely decayed, infected or broken. CDCP covers:
* pulpectomies (first step of a root canal treatment)
#### Periodontal services
These services treat areas around the teeth, including gums and bone. CDCP covers:
* ### Major services
#### Restorative services
These services restore teeth when they’re too damaged to be fixed with basic fillings. CDCP covers:
#### Removable prosthodontic services
These services replace missing teeth. CDCP covers:
#### Oral surgery
These services remove teeth or tumours and fix other problems in the mouth and jaw that need surgery. CDCP covers:
* ### Anesthesia or sedation services
These services provide sedation and pain management during dental procedures.
* ### Orthodontic services
These are not available yet. A specific range of orthodontic services will be available in the future, at a date to be determined. Preauthorization will be required for orthodontic treatment.
For more information on services covered, consult the[CDCP Dental Benefits Guide](https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/dental/dental-care-plan/guide.html) and the [CDCP Dental Benefit Grids](https://www.sunlife.ca/sl/cdcp/en/provider/dental-benefit-grids/)
**Note:** Some services including those beyond established frequency limits require preauthorization by the CDCP. This means your provider will recommend services and the CDCP will confirm whether they will be covered by the plan. This pre-approval must happen before you can receive these services. The decision will take into consideration your oral health history and medical conditions. Not all requests will be approved for coverage. You may still decide to proceed with the services proposed by your provider, even if not covered by the plan and pay for these directly to your provider.
## How much will be covered
The CDCP will reimburse a portion of the cost of your treatment, but it may not pay the full amount. You may have to pay additional charges directly to the oral health provider, if:
* your adjusted family net income is between $70,000 and $89,999
* the cost of your oral health care services is more than what the CDCP will reimburse for these services, or
* you and your oral health provider agree to services that the CDCP doesn’t cover
### Reimbursement for services
Only oral health providers get reimbursed for services covered under the CDCP.
If you are covered by the CDCP, you shouldn’t pay the full cost upfront, but you may have to pay any additional charges directly to the oral health provider.
Please [contact us](https://www.canada.ca/en/services/benefits/dental/dental-care-plan/contact.html) if you have questions or require support.
### Co-payments
You may have a co-payment based on your adjusted family net income. A co-payment is the percentage of the CDCP fees that isn’t covered by the CDCP, and that you will have to pay directly to the oral health provider. Your co-payment is based on your adjusted family net income.
**Co-payments based on adjusted family net income**|Adjusted family net income|How much will the CDCP cover|How much you will cover|
|Lower than $70,000|100% of eligible oral health care service costs will be covered at the CDCP established fees.|0% of the CDCP established fees. You may face additional charges as described below.|
|Between $70,000 and $79,999|60% of eligible oral health care service costs will be covered at the CDCP established fees.|40% of the CDCP established fees. You may face additional fees as described below.|
|Between $80,000 and $89,999|40% of eligible oral health care service costs will be covered at the CDCP established fees.|60% of the CDCP established fees. You may face additional fees as described below.|
### Additional charges
The CDCP fees may not be the same as what providers charge. You may have to pay fees in addition to the potential co-payment if:
* the cost of your oral health care services is more than what the CDCP will reimburse for these services
* you and your oral health provider agree to services that the CDCP doesn’t cover
* dental exams, including complete, routine, specific and emergency exams
* x-rays
* cleaning (scaling)
* sealants

# Homemaking Services
This program currently has a waitlist.
Homemaking services help people who are older, ill or have a disability with tasks so they can remain in their own home. These subsidized services are provided according to rules set by the Province and the City.
Homemaking services are managed through [Comfort Keepers Kingston](https://www.comfortkeepers.ca/kingston/).
Only residents of the City of Kingston are eligible for this service. Housing and Social Services will review your finances to determine if you're eligible for homemaking assistance.
## Services included
*
* Cleaning the bathroom and kitchen
* Dusting, sweeping and vacuuming
* Making meals if there is no alternative available
* Doing the laundry and changing bed sheets

notes: Covers swimming, fitness classes, arts programs, and other registered city recreation activities. Must have MFAP card first.

name: Affordable Housing Programs
description: City of Kingston manages social housing waitlist and affordable housing programs including rent-geared-to-income housing, Ontario Renovates (home modifications for seniors and accessibility), and the Housing First program.
eligibility:
* Grants and forgivable loans available to low-income homeowners to complete urgent repairs or accessibility enhancements
* Capital funding contributions to building new affordable housing units
* Forgivable loans to construct an additional residential unit (I.e. secondary suite) on your property
The Affordable Housing Listing includes properties that have received government funding to keep rents affordable over the long term. Affordable rents are set at below-market levels. For availability, please contact the individual landlords directly. Note that these units are different from rent-geared-to-income housing. If you are looking for rent-geared-to-income options, please visit our [Social Housing webpage](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/community-supports/housing-and-homelessness/social-housing/).
Funding is given on a first-come, first-served basis. There are income limits for this program.
**Household eligibility criteria:**
* At least one household member must be 18 years or older, single person or couple, seniors or families are eligible.
* The household must live in the City of Kingston or Frontenac County.
* The combined gross income of the homeowner must be within income limits.
* Misrepresentation will result in ineligibility and repayment.
* Households that received Kingston-Frontenac Renovates funding twice in the past are not eligible.
* Homes previously funded under Kingston-Frontenac Renovates and later sold are ineligible.
* Eligible properties must not have any second mortgage or lien registered against the property.
**Home repair eligibility:**
* Eligible homes include detached, semi-detached, row houses and certain condos.
* Structural repairs for mobile homes are not eligible. Some other types of repairs may be considered on a case-by-case basis.
* Seasonal dwellings are not eligible.
* Work completed before approval is not eligible.
* Only registered businesses are eligible to complete the work. The Business Number (BN)/ HST Number must be provided.
* Eligible applications are reviewed in the order they are received.
* If eligible, homeowners receive a conditional letter of approval.
* Work completed before the agreement is signed and registered, is not eligible for funding.
* Homes bought with assistance from the Home Ownership Program are not eligible for funding under the Kingston-Frontenac Renovates Program.
Details of funding eligibility
|Eligible House Value|
**Income Thresholds Limits**
|Household Size|Income Limit|Status|
|1-2 Persons|$55,000|Eligible|
|3-4 Persons|$65,000|Eligible|
|5 Persons +|$75,000|Eligible|
Examples of eligible home repairs
The Save on Energy program provides free heating pumps to low-income households. Heat pumps use less energy for heating and cooling homes, allowing you to save on energy all year round. For more information about the program visit the [Save of Energy website](https://saveonenergy.ca/en/For-Your-Home/Energy-Affordability-Program/Air-Source-Heat-Pumps).
The Home Ownership Program helps lower-income households buy affordable homes. It helps people who currently rent a place and want to buy a home in Kingston or Frontenac County by offering a forgivable loan for the down payment.
You might qualify for this program if you are currently renting housing or are a first-time buyer, and would like to buy a home priced at $500,000 or less in the City of Kingston or the County of Frontenac.
**Household eligibility criteria:**
* ****The household must currently live within the city of Kingston or Frontenac County. The household must be living in a rental unit that will be re-rented or be a first-time buyer within the city of Kingston or Frontenac County.
* The household cannot own property
* The total gross income for a one-person household cannot exceed $95,000. A one-person household is a household with one income earner who would be the sole property owner (exclusive of dependent household members).
* The total gross income for a two-person household cannot exceed $130,000. A two-person household is a household with two income earners who contribute to the finances of the household (exclusive of dependents household members).
* Previous program homebuyers are ineligible
* The household must buy their principal residence
* Household members must be Canadian citizens or permanent residents
* The application must include a mortgage pre-approval from a lending institution, eligible lenders include banks, credit unitions, and mortgage investment corporations. Loans with unregulated or private lenders are ineligible
* Applications with mortgage pre-approval supported by a co-signer or guarantor are not eligible
**Eligible home purchases:**
* Mobile homes are not eligible
* Multi-residential properties are not eligible
* Applicants who have made an offer on a property prior to application approval are ineligible.
* Eligible applications are reviewed in the order they are received
* If the property is sold during the 20-year term, or the property is no longer the principal residence of the household, the loan plus 10% of any capital appreciation is to be repaid to the City
* All adult household members must provide certain documents and meet income and asset criteria
Social housing is a type of government-supported housing. It provides lower-cost rental units or a housing allowance to households with low-to-moderate incomes. Social housing is governed by the [Housing Services Act, 2011](https://www.ontario.ca/laws/statute/11h06). All providers are requested to comply with the [Social Housing Directives](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/community-supports/housing-and-homelessness/social-housing/social-housing-directives/).
* Rent-Geared-to Income Housing
The programs offered are based on the household income and assets. A household is defined as all people who will be living in the same unit.
## Rent-geared-to-income (RGI) program
RGI means that the rent you pay for housing is based on your income. Generally, RGI rent is calculated at 30 percent of a household’s income. This is based on each household member's Notice of Assessment (annual income tax return). If your only source of income is Ontario Works (OW) or Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP), the rent is based on a rent scale set by the Ontario Government.
A PHB is a monthly subsidy for low-income households to help with housing costs. It provides eligible households with a monthly payment to help with rental costs in the private rental market. The benefit belongs to the individual and can be used to help pay rent anywhere in Kingston or the County of Frontenac, even if you move.
Unlike RGI assistance, this benefit is linked to the household, not a specific place. It lets the household move to any rental unit in the City of Kingston or the County of Frontenac. This gives recipients the flexibility to live closer to family, support networks, schools, or work.
Households must already pay rent in their current unit or find their own private rental market housing in the City of Kingston or the County of Frontenac.
The monthly benefit is calculated using your household’s adjusted family net income (AFNI) as reported on your annual Notice of Assessment Line 23600. It is also based on the amount of rent you pay, and the Average Market Rent (AMR) assessed by the Ontario government for Kingston.
If you are single and in receipt of ODSP and your AFNI = $16,056, your ODSP shelter allowance is $599, and your rent is $1,700. You are eligible for a 1 bedroom which as an AMR of $1,409.
1. New applicants start by filling out a Rent-Geared-to-Income Application with the Housing Registry (the Registry). If something is missing or incomplete with the application, you will be notified within 7 business days. If we do not receive the information or have not been contacted by you, we will cancel the application after 90 days (about 3 months).
2. If your application is complete, you will be notified within 30 days (about a month) to let you know if you are eligible or not. If you are eligible, your name will be placed on the centralized waitlist (CWL), and you will be assigned to a Community Programs Caseworker who will be your worker for the duration you are waiting for an RGI unit or a PHB
* The size of unit you qualify for.
Please note, these are averages. Some households have been waiting for longer than 14 years to be housed due to the factors listed above.
The only households who get faster access to housing in Kingston and Frontenac County are those who have been granted Special Priority Status. In 2023, the average wait time was 6 months for Special Priority applicants.
Eligibility requirements for RGI and PHB
* At least one member of the household must be 16 years of age or older and be able to live independently without support services or can arrange their own support.
* Each member of the household must be a Canadian Citizen, a Permanent Resident of Canada, a Refugee Claimant, or has made an application to become a Permanent Resident.
* No member of the household owes money to any social housing provider in Ontario. You can apply if there is a repayment agreement which is in good standing.
* No household member has been convicted of misrepresenting their income to receive RGI assistance in the past 2 years.
* If any member of your household owns residential property suitable for year-round occupancy, they must agree to sell the property within 6 months of moving into RGI housing or receiving a PHB.
* Your total household income must be under the household income limits, depending upon your eligible unit size. The maximum number of bedrooms allowed is one bedroom per single or couple plus an additional bedroom for each household member.
* Total household assets must be under $50,000 for single applicants and under $75,000 for families.
Maximum income limits for households
The Ontario government sets the maximum income limits based on your unit type.
As someone applying for social housing, it's your job to keep your information up to date to stay on the CWL and to maintain your eligibility. You should let the Registry know about any changes within 30 days (about a month) after they happen.
If you are a victim of abuse, you need to fill out a [special priority application](#rgiforms). You can include this form with your RGI application or send it separately. You need to be eligible for RGI before you can be granted special priority.
If you are eligible for RGI and have been granted special priority, your name will be placed above those already on the CWL.
1. Download and complete the [Rent-Geared-to-Income (RGI) Housing Application](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/media/4epgsmdh/socialservices_form_rentgearedtoincomeassistance.pdf) and required supporting information.
* [RGI Additional Household Members](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/media/fhtlvxl1/socialservices_form_additionalhouseholdmembers.pdf)
* [Annual Eligibility Review](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/media/s4ybkrey/hss_form_annualeligibilityreview.pdf)
Make sure your application is complete and provide a copy of Canadian citizenship, permanent residency, or refugee status for every household member aged 16 or older.
Tenants who are eligible for RGI usually pay 30 percent of their monthly income as rent. If you receive OW or ODSP, the rent is based on a rent benefit set by the Ontario government. Depending on your housing, you might also pay for utilities. A utility allowance is subtracted from your rent if you are expected to pay for your own utilities. If utilities are included, you may be required to pay extra for your rent.
Yes, the lease agreement must be signed by everyone who is a member of the household and is at least 16 years old.
Tenants can ask for a review of rent changes once per year between annual review, if your household’s income has decreased by more than 20% since your annual review.
how_to_apply:
How to apply
If you want to receive funding from the Kingston-Frontenac Renovates Program:
1. Read the program guidelines and requirements
2. Download and complete the [pdf application](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/media/zj0hnlgv/housing_form_kingstonfrontenacrenovates.pdf)
3. Gather all the required documents
4. Login/signup to MyKingston and upload the complete PDF form and any additional supporting information through the [Housing Programs intake form](https://www.mykingston.ca/-/services/housing-programs-intake).
Applicants can expect to hear back about their application within two weeks.
* The total assets of the homeowner must not exceed $20,000. Registered investments, including RRSP, RDSP, RRIF, are excluded from the asset calculation. TFSA, non-registered investment accounts, and funds in savings and chequing accounts are included in the asset calculation.
* Eligible properties must not have any second mortgage or lien registered against the property.
* At the end of the ten-year forgiveness period, homeowners can request removal of registered documents at their expense.
* The home must be at least 10 years old unless the application is for 'accessibility' improvements.
* Only registered businesses are eligible to complete the work. The Business Number (BN)/ HST Number must be provided.
**Application and selection process:**
* Submit a complete application with required documents.
* Applications must be delivered to the Housing and Social Services Department.
* Eligible applications are reviewed in the order they are received.
* Work completed before the agreement is signed and registered, is not eligible for funding.
* Loan agreements over $5,000 will be registered on title of the property.
Thank you for your interest in the Home Ownership Program. Applications for the 2025 intake are no longer being accepted. If future funding becomes available, updates will be posted here.
* The combined assets must not exceed $50,000. Assets include recreational vehicles, non-registered investments and cash held in bank accounts. Registered assets (i.e. RRSP, RESP, RIF, RDSP) are exempt. TFSA and FHSA accounts are included in the asset calculation.
* The application must include a mortgage pre-approval from a lending institution, eligible lenders include banks, credit unitions, and mortgage investment corporations. Loans with unregulated or private lenders are ineligible
* Applications with mortgage pre-approval supported by a co-signer or guarantor are not eligible
* Applicants who have made an offer on a property prior to application approval are ineligible.
**Application and Selection:**
* Submit a complete application with required documents
* Eligible applications are reviewed in the order they are received
* The agreement will be registered on title of the property at the home owner’s expense on the closing date
* Applications continue until all funding is distributed
* It is a 20-year interest-free forgivable loan registered on the property's title
* The City and the developer enter into a contribution agreement which is registered on title of the property during the affordability period
Our Additional Residential Unit (ARU) Incentive Program, helps property owners create more housing options in the city. The program offers five types of financial support, including forgivable loans and non-repayable grants, to those who meet its conditions. If you receive a forgivable loan, you won’t have to repay it if you follow the program rules for five years. We review and approve applications on a first-come, first-served basis while funding is available. Learn more about [the program and how to apply](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/building-and-renovating/building-permits/additional-residential-units-arus/aru-incentive-programs/).
1. New applicants start by filling out a Rent-Geared-to-Income Application with the Housing Registry (the Registry). If something is missing or incomplete with the application, you will be notified within 7 business days. If we do not receive the information or have not been contacted by you, we will cancel the application after 90 days (about 3 months).
2. If your application is complete, you will be notified within 30 days (about a month) to let you know if you are eligible or not. If you are eligible, your name will be placed on the centralized waitlist (CWL), and you will be assigned to a Community Programs Caseworker who will be your worker for the duration you are waiting for an RGI unit or a PHB
4. There is a waitlist for each housing choice listed in the RGI application as well as for the PHB. When a selected property or benefit becomes available, the housing provider, not the Registry, will offer it to the next person on the list. You will need to respond within two business days. If you refuse an offer of housing, you will be removed from the CWL. If you refuse a PHB, you will remain on the list for the RGI properties you selected as choices.
* Each member of the household must be a Canadian Citizen, a Permanent Resident of Canada, a Refugee Claimant, or has made an application to become a Permanent Resident.
* Any other information or document on your application changes
Even if nothing has changed in your details, we need to hear from you at least once a year just to keep your application active.
If you are a victim of abuse, you need to fill out a [special priority application](#rgiforms). You can include this form with your RGI application or send it separately. You need to be eligible for RGI before you can be granted special priority.

## Kingston-Frontenac Renovates Program
The Kingston-Frontenac Renovates Program helps homeowners by providing funding assistance to complete urgent repairs or to make their homes more accessible. You can get up to $15,000 as a forgivable loan, and, up to $5,000, you don't need to pay back if you use it for accessibility projects. If you continue to live in your home for ten years, you do not have to pay back the loan.
Funding is given on a first-come, first-served basis. There are income limits for this program.
How to apply
1. Read the program guidelines and requirements
2. Download and complete the [pdf application](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/media/zj0hnlgv/housing_form_kingstonfrontenacrenovates.pdf)
4. Login/signup to MyKingston and upload the complete PDF form and any additional supporting information through the [Housing Programs intake form](https://www.mykingston.ca/-/services/housing-programs-intake).
Applicants can expect to hear back about their application within two weeks.
Kingston-Frontenac Renovates program guidelines and requirements
**Household eligibility criteria:**
* At least one household member must be 18 years or older, single person or couple, seniors or families are eligible.
* The household must live in the City of Kingston or Frontenac County.
* The combined gross income of the homeowner must be within income limits.
* The total assets of the homeowner must not exceed $20,000. Registered investments, including RRSP, RDSP, RRIF, are excluded from the asset calculation. TFSA, non-registered investment accounts, and funds in savings and chequing accounts are included in the asset calculation.
* The homeowner must not have an interest in other property or be applying for bankruptcy.
* Misrepresentation will result in ineligibility and repayment.
* Households that received Kingston-Frontenac Renovates funding twice in the past are not eligible.
* Homes previously funded under Kingston-Frontenac Renovates and later sold are ineligible.
* Eligible properties must not have any second mortgage or lien registered against the property.
**Home repair eligibility:**
* The home must be at least 10 years old unless the application is for 'accessibility' improvements.
* Eligible homes include detached, semi-detached, row houses and certain condos.
* Structural repairs for mobile homes are not eligible. Some other types of repairs may be considered on a case-by-case basis.
* Seasonal dwellings are not eligible.
* Work completed before approval is not eligible.
* Funding is only for approved repairs, including certain related costs.

* For accessibility projects, a medical note from a doctor, physiotherapist, or occupational therapist is required.
* Homeowners are responsible for the costs of any additional, unapproved work.
* Selling, transferring, or renting the home before the end of the ten-year term will require repayment of the loan forgiven at a rate of ten per cent per year.

Social housing is a type of government-supported housing. It provides lower-cost rental units or a housing allowance to households with low-to-moderate incomes. Social housing is governed by the [Housing Services Act, 2011](https://www.ontario.ca/laws/statute/11h06). All providers are requested to comply with the [Social Housing Directives](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/community-supports/housing-and-homelessness/social-housing/social-housing-directives/).
A PHB is a monthly subsidy for low-income households to help with housing costs. It provides eligible households with a monthly payment to help with rental costs in the private rental market. The benefit belongs to the individual and can be used to help pay rent anywhere in Kingston or the County of Frontenac, even if you move.

Older Adult Services | City of Kingston
# Older Adult Services
## Age-friendly communities
## Programs to help you at home
Staying in your home programs means you can save on taxes, get assistance with household tasks and receive help from your neighbours and local community.
### Older adults tax assistance programs
We offer tax assistance programs to help with taxes for older adults, especially when they retire and their finances change. This ensures they follow tax rules and get the support they require. Learn more about application requirements on our [tax assistance and rebates page](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/property-taxes/tax-assistance-and-rebates/).
* **Senior Property Tax Credit program:** Older adults getting the Guaranteed Income Supplement can get a $100 tax credit
* **Tax deferral program:** Older adults who own a home and get the Guaranteed Income Supplement can defer paying up to $1,000 in taxes
### Home help and maintenance
The [Seniors Association](https://seniorskingston.ca/) offers various support programs, connecting older adults with service providers who can help with tasks like home maintenance, shopping and cleaning. You can reach them at [613-548-7810](tel:613-548-7810) for assistance.
Additionally, [subsidized homemaking services](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/community-supports/homemaking-services/) are available to support elderly, disabled, ill or recovering individuals, enabling them to continue living in their own homes.
### Community supports
If you are not sure where to get help, you can dial 211 on any phone. It is a free call and customer service reps are ready to assist you 24/7 to connect you with community resources. You can also visit their website [211 Ontario](https://211ontario.ca/search/) for information on various support services for older adults.
## Staying active
### Recreation
* [Open gym, badminton and pickleball](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/activities-and-recreation/drop-in-recreational-programs/sports-programs/)
### Getting around
Getting around Kingston is easy with Kingston Transit. Use the [trip planner](https://www.kingstontransit.ca/trip-planner/) to help you plan your outing. If you need other transportation, visit [Kingston Access Services](https://www.kingstonaccessbus.net/).
### Accessibility
We are committed to making sure everyone in our community can use City programs, services and facilities. If you have any questions or would like additional details about our dedication to accessibility, available resources, or our [Municipal Accessibility Advisory Committee](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/council-and-city-administration/committees-and-boards/municipal-accessibility-advisory-committee/), please visit the [Indigenization, Inclusion, Diversity, Equity and Accessibility](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/council-and-city-administration/indigenization-inclusion-diversity-equity-and-accessibility-iidea/) page to learn more.
Have an accessibility related question or want to report a concern? [Contact us](https://mycity.cityofkingston.ca/app/ask).
### Volunteering
## Staying informed
* If you have any questions or concerns, please [contact us](https://www.cityofkingston.ca/council-and-city-administration/contact-us/)
Contact Us
[contactus@cityofkingston.ca](mailto:contactus@cityofkingston.ca)
Phone: [613-546-0000](tel:613-546-0000)
In Kingston, about 21 per cent of our population is 65 or older. This number has steadily been growing over the last 20 years. We are currently seeing a record number of the working age population entering retirement as the population over 65 continues to grow!
In recent years, Kingston has been working to make the city more welcoming for older adults as part of the ‘age-friendly’ initiative by the World Health Organization. In 2015, we asked adults (45 and up) about things like activities, safety, health and how friendly they found the city for older adults.
During these efforts, older adults told us four main things:
*
* They want to keep living in their own homes
* They want to be part of the Kingston community and do things
* They want to know where to find help when they need it
* They want people to treat them with respect
*
We offer different activities for older adults to keep their minds busy and maintain a healthy and fulfilling lifestyle.
We offer a variety of recreational programs adjusted to the needs and interests of older adults. We also collaborate with the [Seniors Association to provide a range of programs](https://seniorskingston.ca/programs)that help you stay active, keep learning and stay engaged.

If you are not sure where to get help, you can dial 211 on any phone. It is a free call and customer service reps are ready to assist you 24/7 to connect you with community resources. You can also visit their website [211 Ontario](https://211ontario.ca/search/) for information on various support services for older adults.
We offer a variety of recreational programs adjusted to the needs and interests of older adults. We also collaborate with the [Seniors Association to provide a range of programs](https://seniorskingston.ca/programs)that help you stay active, keep learning and stay engaged.

description: Delivers hot, nutritious meals to the homes of seniors and individuals with disabilities in Kingston who have difficulty preparing their own meals.
eligibility: Kingston residents who are homebound or have difficulty preparing meals due to age, illness, or disability.
how_to_apply: Call Victorian Order of Nurses (VON) Kingston at 613-542-7293 to arrange meal delivery.

name: Kingston Caregiver Support
description: Support services for family caregivers of older adults in Kingston, including respite care, support groups, and information. Provided through SE Health and community partners.
eligibility: Family caregivers of older adults or persons with disabilities in Kingston.
how_to_apply: Call SE Health at 613-544-7090 or contact the Alzheimer Society of KFL&A at 613-544-3078.

name: Ontario Senior Homeowners Property Tax Grant
description: Ontario provides a property tax grant of up to $500/year for senior homeowners with low-to-moderate income. Claimed when filing your income tax return.
eligibility: Ontario residents aged 64+ who own their home and have income under $50,000 (single) or $60,000 (couple).
address: Claimed through CRA when filing taxes
how_to_apply: File your annual income tax return and claim the Ontario Senior Homeowners' Property Tax Grant on the ON-BEN form.

name: Ontario Drug Benefit (ODB)
description: Covers most prescription drug costs for Ontario residents aged 65+. Covers over 5,000 drug products. Annual deductible of $100, then co-pay of $6.11 per prescription.
eligibility:
Get help paying for prescription drugs when you qualify for the Ontario Drug Benefit program.
## Who can qualify
You will qualify for the Ontario Drug Benefit (ODB) program when you turn **65 years old**. You will qualify before you reach that age because you’re:
* living in a:
* long-term care home
* home for special care
* Community Home for Opportunity
* 24 years of age or younger and not covered by a private insurance plan
If you are a low-income senior or a senior couple with income below certain thresholds, you can have your Ontario Drug Benefit deductible waived and co-payment fees reduced to $2 by applying for the [Seniors Co-Payment Program](https://www.ontario.ca/page/seniors-ontario-drug-benefit-deductible-and-prescription-co-payment). The Ontario Drug Benefit program is for**Ontario residents only**and prescriptions must be**filled in an Ontario pharmacy**to be covered. Make sure your Ontario health card is valid (for example, it hasn’t expired). Your pharmacist will need your health card to confirm your eligibility for the Ontario Drug Benefit program.

If you become pregnant during a specified transition period, or require palliative care during a specified transition period, then you may be eligible to continue receiving ODB program coverage for the originator biologic for a limited time if you meet certain criteria. This exception may not apply if the biologic is not indicated for use in palliative care and/or pregnant patients. Please consult your pharmacist or prescriber for more information.

#### Calculating first-year deductible
For your first year of Ontario Drug Benefit program eligibility, depending on the month you turn 65, the deductible **may be lower than $100**.

Get coverage for prescription drugs | ontario.ca
# Get coverage for prescription drugs
Get help paying for prescription drugs when you qualify for the Ontario Drug Benefit program.
##
## Who can qualify
You will qualify for the Ontario Drug Benefit (ODB) program when you turn **65 years old**. You will qualify before you reach that age because you’re:
* 24 years of age or younger and not covered by a private insurance plan
* receiving professional home and community care services
* receiving benefits from [Ontario Works](https://www.mcss.gov.on.ca/en/mcss/programs/social/ow/) or [Ontario Disability Support Program](https://www.ontario.ca/page/ontario-disability-support-program)
* enrolled in the [Trillium Drug Program](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-help-high-prescription-drug-costs)
For **seniors **(people 65 years and older), we will send you a letter about 3 months before your 65th birthday to let you know you will **automatically join** the Ontario Drug Benefit program on the first day of the month after you turn 65 years old.
If you are a low-income senior or a senior couple with income below certain thresholds, you can have your Ontario Drug Benefit deductible waived and co-payment fees reduced to $2 by applying for the [Seniors Co-Payment Program](https://www.ontario.ca/page/seniors-ontario-drug-benefit-deductible-and-prescription-co-payment). The Ontario Drug Benefit program is for**Ontario residents only**and prescriptions must be**filled in an Ontario pharmacy**to be covered. Make sure your Ontario health card is valid (for example, it hasn’t expired). Your pharmacist will need your health card to confirm your eligibility for the Ontario Drug Benefit program.
## What’s covered
The Ontario Drug Benefit program covers**most of the cost of approximately 5,000**prescription drug products.
[Search for covered drugs](https://www.ontario.ca/check-medication-coverage)
* [allergy shots and epinephrine injectable products (used in response to severe allergic reaction)](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-coverage-prescription-drugs#allergy)
* [some products used in monitoring and testing for diabetes](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-coverage-prescription-drugs#diabetes)
* [some prescribed over-the-counter drugs](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-coverage-prescription-drugs#overthecounter)under specific circumstances
* [some nutrition products](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-coverage-prescription-drugs#nutrition)
* [some drugs used in the treatment ofHIV/AIDS](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-coverage-prescription-drugs#HIV)
* [some drugs used in palliative care](https://www.ontario.ca/page/get-coverage-prescription-drugs#palliative)
The Ontario Drug Benefit program covers 100% of the cost of your **allergy shots and epinephrine injectable products **(for example, **auto-injectors**), which are used in response to severe allergic reactions.
Antihistamines and mixtures used in testing for allergies are not covered by the ODB program.
### Diabetes products
Some products used to monitor and test for diabetes are covered by the Ontario Drug Benefit program.
This includes diabetic testing strips for measuring blood glucose (sugar) – a common product prescribed by doctors or nurse practitioners to patients living with diabetes.
#### Diabetic testing strips
The Ontario Drug Benefit program covers the cost for a maximum number of diabetic testing strips based on your current treatment method and clinical guidelines set by the Diabetes Canada.
This table shows the type of treatment and number of test strips covered.
|Patients managing diabetes|Maximum number of strips (per year) covered|
#### Qualifying for other programs
Syringes, lancets, glucometers and other diabetic supplies**are not covered**by theODBprogram. However, other programs may help you pay for products.
Find out if you qualify for other coverage through:
Some drugs can be purchased without a prescription (also called over-the-counter drugs), if you pay for them yourself. The Ontario Drug Benefit Program may cover the cost of these drugs but only if your physician or nurse practitioner gives you a prescription for them and if the drugs are either:
* covered through the [Exceptional Access Program (EAP)](https://www.ontario.ca/page/applying-exceptional-access-program#section-1)
For the Exceptional Access Program to cover an over-the-counter drug:
* your doctor or nurse practitioner must send us a request for coverage
If you think that the cost of an over-the-counter drug should be covered, check with your healthcare provider before buying the drug to avoid out-of-pocket costs.
### Nutrition products
The Ontario Drug Benefit program covers the cost of nutrition products up to a maximum dollar amount. The product **must be your sole source of nutrition** and be prescribed by your doctor or nurse practitioner.

notes:
The Ontario Drug Benefit program does not cover the cost of a nutrition product if you’re able to eat some solid foods, as noted by your doctor or nurse practitioner. It also does not cover a nutritional product used for:
* supplementing other foods
* weight loss (even if directed by a doctor or nurse practitioner) to treat obesity
If your doctor or nurse practitioner is not registered on the Palliative Care Facilitated Access List, the drugs may still be covered if your doctor or nurse practitioner submits a coverage request to the [Exceptional Access Program](https://www.ontario.ca/page/applying-exceptional-access-program) either by [fax](https://www.ontario.ca/page/applying-exceptional-access-program#section-2) or by calling the Exceptional Access Program’s [telephone request service](https://www.ontario.ca/page/exceptional-access-program#section-3). Note that you will also need to consult with a doctor or nurse practitioner who is registered on the Palliative Care Facilitated Access List if you are requesting a high strength opioid through the Exceptional Access Program, including the telephone request service.
* Copaxone® (glatiramer)[footnote 1[1]](#foot-1)
If you’re taking another biologic not listed above that the ODB program covers, it will still be covered. As new biosimilars are approved by Health Canada and enter the Canadian market, additional biologic drugs may be subject to this transition requirement and this webpage will be updated to reflect the applicable biologic drug and transition period.
Additionally, if you have a medical reason why you can’t switch to the biosimilar, your specialist, doctor or nurse practitioner may request an exemption for you that will be considered on a case-by-case basis through the [Exceptional Access Program](https://www.ontario.ca/page/exceptional-access-program).
**Note:** if you’ve lost the official prescription receipt, you can ask the pharmacist to provide you with the Patient Medical Expense Report (PMER) as proof of your prescription receipt document. The PMER must have a pharmacy stamp and pharmacist’s signature and it must contain the same information as an official prescription receipt:

## Description of the Guaranteed Income Supplement
The Guaranteed Income Supplement (GIS) is a**monthly payment**you can get if you are **65 or older.**
The Supplement is based on income and is available to Old Age Security pensioners with low income. It is not taxable.
## You may have to apply for the Guaranteed Income Supplement if
* You are already receiving your Old Age Security pension and never applied for the Guaranteed Income Supplement
If you have general questions about the Guaranteed Income Supplement or specific questions about your application, [contact us](https://www.canada.ca/en/employment-social-development/corporate/contact/oas.html).
